message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has gross hematuria and a pelvic fracture, suggesting the possibility of bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step to evaluate for this possibility. Intravenous pyelography is not indicated, as there is no indication of an upper urinary tract injury. External fixation of the pelvis is not indicated at present. Retrograde urethrography is not indicated, as there is no evidence of urethral injury on physical examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hematuria and a pelvic fracture, which increases the risk of bladder injury. Retrograde cystography can help diagnose a bladder injury and guide treatment. Intravenous pyelography is not useful for this situation, and external fixation of the pelvis is not necessary if there is no pelvic instability. Retrograde urethrography is not needed if there is no blood at the urethral meatus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. A fracture of the pelvis and gross hematuria indicate possible bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step in management to assess for bladder injury. Intravenous pyelography and retrograde urethrography are not indicated in this case. External fixation of the pelvis may be necessary, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The gross hematuria after placement of a Foley catheter indicates a bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step in management to diagnose the extent of the injury and guide further treatment. Intravenous pyelography and retrograde urethrography are not indicated in this case, and external fixation of the pelvis is not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a pelvic fracture and gross hematuria, which suggests bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step to assess for bladder injury. Intravenous pyelography is used to assess the renal system, and external fixation would not address the bladder injury. Retrograde urethrography would only be indicated if there was concern for urethral injury, which is not the case in this scenario.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has gross hematuria after a high-speed motor vehicle collision, suggesting bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step in management to assess for bladder injury. Intravenous pyelography is not indicated in this case. External fixation of the pelvis may be necessary but is not the most appropriate next step. Retrograde urethrography may be indicated in cases of urethral injury, but the patient’s urethral meatus was normal on examination.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Pelvic fracture and gross hematuria suggest the possibility of bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is used to diagnose bladder injury and would be the most appropriate next step in management. Intravenous pyelography is used to evaluate the urinary tract but is not indicated in this case. External fixation of the pelvis is not indicated for bladder injury. Retrograde urethrography is used to evaluate urethral injury, but there is no indication of urethral injury in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with severe lower abdominal and pelvic pain with gross hematuria, indicating a possible bladder injury. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step in management to visualize the bladder and check for injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Erectile cystography can help diagnose a bladder rupture, which is a common complication of pelvic fractures. The patient has gross hematuria and a fracture on the left pelvic edge, which increases the likelihood of a bladder rupture. Intravenous pyelography is indicated when there is suspicion of kidney injury or ureteric injury, but the patient has no sign of renal injury. External fixation is not indicated in this case. Retrograde urethrography is indicated when there is suspicion of urethral injury, but there is no blood at the urethral meatus.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has gross hematuria and a fracture of the left pelvic edge, suggesting a possible injury to the bladder. Retrograde cystography is the most appropriate next step in management to evaluate for bladder injury. Intravenous pyelography is not relevant to this case, and external fixation of the pelvis would not address the potential bladder injury. Retrograde urethrography would only be indicated if there were urethral injury, which is not suggested by the examination findings.
